llm_response.description: The retinal fundus image shows multiple dark spots consistent with microaneurysms and hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also lighter areas that may represent exudates. No clear signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots are visible. The presence of these features suggests non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without any signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina without signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots or other lesions indicative of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows several dark spots suggestive of microaneurysms and possible hemorrhages in the central region. There are no visible signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots. The optic disc appears normal, and there are no significant venous changes or exudates observed.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and the surrounding retinal area. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present. The overall appearance suggests no significant signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without any venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright spots consistent with hard exudates scattered across the retina. There are also several dark spots that may represent microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no obvious neovascularization or significant venous changes. Cotton wool spots are not clearly visible.

The retinal fundus image shows several features indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as larger, darker red areas. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white spots, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft, fluffy white patches, are visible, suggesting nerve fiber layer infarctions. No significant venous beading or neovascularization is observed in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc on the left with clear margins. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the disc. The macula appears slightly darker and is located centrally. There are multiple small yellowish-white spots scattered throughout the retina, which are consistent with hard exudates. No obvious microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization are observed.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no apparent signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as larger, darker red spots. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white spots, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft, fluffy white patches, are visible, suggesting nerve fiber layer infarctions. No significant neovascularization is observed. The presence of these features suggests moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of multiple bright yellow-white spots, which are likely hard exudates, located in the central and peripheral regions. There are also several dark red spots that could represent microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no obvious neovascularization or significant venous beading. Cotton wool spots are not clearly visible in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright yellow-white spots consistent with hard exudates, primarily located in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are also several dark red spots indicative of microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or significant venous changes. Cotton wool spots are not clearly visible.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also several hard exudates visible, particularly in the superior region. Cotton wool spots are present, indicating localized ischemia. The optic disc appears slightly blurred, and there is evidence of venous beading. No neovascularization is observed.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple hard exudates arranged in a circinate pattern, which are bright yellow-white lesions. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization visible in this image. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula is not clearly visible due to the presence of exudates.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple yellowish-white spots in the macular region, indicative of hard exudates. There are also several small red dots scattered throughout the retina, suggestive of microaneurysms. No significant hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization are observed.
